newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.Africa's SAA to meet union at 1530 GMT.
newsitem.headline: S.Africa's SAA to meet union at 1530 GMT.

text.p: A meeting has been set for 1530 GMT on Thursday to resolve the nine-day impasse between South African Airways (SAA) and the union representing aviation technicians and engineers.
"A meeting has been set for 1730 (1530 GMT) today with the union to resolve the matter," SAA spokesman Leon Els told Reuters.

South African Aviation Engineering and Allied Union (SAAEAU) president Joe Joubert said the minister of public enterprises Stella Sigcau met seperately with the union and SAA and urged them to go the route of mediation.

"The minister asked to be briefed on the situation. She urged us to settle this by mediation. The union will be meeting with the company at (1530 GMT) today to set up the terms of reference for mediation," Joubert told Reuters.
The 2,200-strong union has declared a dispute with SAA because of its refusal to offer a 25 percent wage rise. Management is offering a 10 percent increase plus a 20 percent productivity bonus.
SAAEAU suspended a work-to rule campaign on Tuesday afternoon on condition that mediation was resumed. SAA refused and locked out about 1,800 union members on Wednesday.

The union applied for a court interdict on Wednesday to stop SAA from issuing letters to locked-out union members calling on them to agree to the airline's wage offer and end their week-long work-to-rule protest action.
The industrial court dismissed the application with costs.
SAA officials said most flights left on schedule on Thursday after the flight programme was rearranged on Wednesday. But the situation was still the same with regards to the lock-out.
Els said: "Not many more (workers) have returned to work (on Thursday."
SAA said the week-long go-slow and lock-out had cost it about 40 million rand so far.
